His childhood friend Alice Nam(ph) says in high school, Moon was constantly goofing off.
But then he graduated, joined the Army and he quickly matured, she says, as he patrolled the border in his homeland of South Korea.
Then in 2005, the Army sent him to Iraq.
I knew like, you know, he had trouble sleeping, and like adjusting from like becoming like a civilian into becoming a soldier.
And that coming back home on like block leave, and becoming a civilian again was just like really hard on him.
And after he left the Army, he came back.
And he came back a man, and like a leader.
The Army called Moon for a second tour of duty in October.
His family worried about his safety.
But then his father, Young Moon(ph), got a call from his son in Christmas Eve.
He told his father he was doing well.
That is that my family Christmas present, because my son was okay.
He's good.
After that day, Christmas Day, around 3 o'clock, two soldiers have been coming.
They say I'm sorry, you're son has been die.
In the Moon household outside Philadelphia is a memorial to the fallen soldier.
A day after the funeral, a steady flow of visitors - many of Korean descent - come into the house and lay out flowers.
They stare into the pictures of Moon in his military uniform and bow in respect.
His mother, Ki Moon(ph), sits in armchair weeping as her daughter consoles her.
And then among the flow of visitors, a man wearing a military uniform enters, carrying a bouquet of flowers.
He is Staff Sergeant Daniel Eskemiah(ph), Moon's squad leader from his tour of South Korea.
On behalf of my battalion commander and the sergeant major, present you with these flowers.

If there's no evidence that the surge is working, the policy is working, then perhaps even some Republicans who've stayed with the Republican - with the president on this vote may not be so loyal to the president come September 30th.
There are those, as you've noted, and they include the Democratic presidential hopeful John Edwards, who say the president vetoed it, just send him the same bill again.
And if he wants to veto it, he is the one cutting off the funding for the troops.
Right.

There you go.
I'm sorry.
He says that, look, every now and then reality has to step in here and we should just get it done and then deal with the next one down the line.

But it is interesting how the presidential candidates have to deal with this, because some people say that Hillary Clinton is looking beyond a Democratic electorate, looking toward the general election strategy.

And if that's the case - we saw in the debate that she was, you know, boning up on her foreign policy strengths - perhaps she just says she'll say the same thing, too, that maybe we just send back a cleaner bill.
Something, yes, that the president wants, but by the next go-around that he doesn't get his way.
Here is an email from Doug(ph) in Kingston, Missouri.
Bush has received much publicity for his use of the signing statement allowing him to pick and choose what he accepts in a bill.
Why can't he do the same to the Iraq funding bill?
Well, it's sort of like, I mean, you know, when President Bush says he's going to do something - at least we saw it before with stem-cell research.
The veto he hasâ€¦
That's the only other veto he's cast in his entire time in office.
And he said this is completely unacceptable, there's no way what the politicians have to say will outweigh what the military commanders on the field say.
That's what President Bush says.
And so, from the beginning, he said he was not going to back down, he was going to veto it.
And that's what he did yesterday.
Now how much of a bind does this put, particularly in the Senate, some of the more moderate Republicans?
Well, that's a very good point also because you have a handful of them up for reelection in 2008.
Twenty one of the 33 senators up are Republicans, and you have people like John Sununu in New Hampshire, Norm Coleman in Minnesota, Gordon Smith of Oregon, Susan Collins in Maine.
These people are really not gung-ho on the war.
They've really soured on the war.
And voters back home are going to be watching them very closely to see how they vote on this as well.

This is Jason, Jason with us from San Antonio.
Hey.
Good afternoon.
I got a question about why the president vetoed this bill, because the timetables for withdrawal were non-binding in every report I heard.
And I don't understand why he couldn't have just signed it and let it move on and then, you know, proceeded at his wish.
That was out of the conference committee, where the House version of the bill, which is a little more specific, was melded with the Senate version of the bill, which was, as Jason says, non-binding.
There were no specific timeframes for this.
Well, except what Congress did pass, led by the Democratic majorities, that the beginning of the troop withdrawals would begin this year, October 1st, and then gradually over the next year.
Yes, he could have ignored it.
He could have probably fudged it in some way.
But I think the president really felt very strongly.
He wanted to make a statement.

I think he feels that, unlike the war, which is very unpopular with the American people, he has a case to make about the funding, whether the Democrats are being obstructionist or cut-and-runners or whatever he wants to call it.
But I think he feels that he has a case if only in the short run, a case to make before the American people.
The longer this goes on I think the advantage goes to the Democrats.
Jason, thanks.

Let's move on to another issue.
A congressional task force has voted to investigate a disputed election in Florida's 13th Congressional District.
Disputed election in Florida, who could have guessed?
Tell us more about it.
And let me guess.
I think the district was once held by Katherine Harris.
Whew!
This is the 13th district in Florida that Katherine Harris gave up to run for the Senate last year.
It was a very, very close race.
Officially, Vern Buchanan, the Republican, was declared the winner by 359 votes against the Democrat Christine Jennings.
And then upon further investigation apparently some 10,000 votes were never counted by these automatic machine.
Democrats said this is a conspiracy.
It was stolen from us.
There should be at the minimum a redo, a do-over.
The Republicans said that's nonsensical.

Ultimately, what it looked like happened is that the way the ballot - I'm not making excuses for anybody - but it looks like the way the ballot was designed so that it looks like the House race was part of the Senate contest and the people just didn't see the votes.
Some thousand people, 10,000 people, did not cast votes in the congressional race.
They voted for Senate, they voted for governor, but not the House race.
Democrats said these people were disenfranchised, there should be a new election.
The House Administration Committee voted two to one - two Democrats to one Republican.
Ah-ha.
